**Gun‑buyback programs – a quick primer**

| Element | What it usually looks like | Typical variations |
|---------|---------------------------|--------------------|
| **Who runs it?** | Local police departments, municipal governments, or non‑profit groups (often with police sponsorship). | State‑wide or national campaigns (e.g., Australia’s 1996 “National Firearms Amnesty”). |
| **How are guns collected?** | Owners bring firearms to a designated site (police station, community center, school parking lot, etc.). | Mobile “drop‑off” trucks, mail‑in options, or “amnesty” windows where no questions are asked. |
| **What do participants receive?** | Cash or a voucher of equal value to the firearm (often $100–$500 per gun, sometimes higher for rifles). | Non‑cash incentives (gift cards, “thank‑you” certificates), or simply a “no‑questions‑asked” guarantee. |
| **Is participation mandatory?** | **No** – most programs are entirely voluntary and anonymous. | Some jurisdictions combine voluntary buybacks with mandatory surrender provisions (e.g., after a court order or during a licensing renewal). |
| **Which guns are accepted?** | Usually all hand‑guns, rifles, shotguns, and sometimes “ghost guns” or parts. | Some programs restrict to hand‑guns or to weapons that are not legally registered. |
| **Funding source** | City or state budgets, federal grants, private foundations, or a mix. | In a few cases, a levy on firearm sales or a portion of a “gun tax.” |
| **Public‑outreach component** | Media announcements, flyers, social‑media ads, community‑leader endorsements. | Partnerships with schools, faith groups, or “gun‑safety” NGOs to increase trust. |

In short, a buy‑back is a **voluntary, incentive‑based exchange** that removes firearms from private hands without imposing penalties on the owners. The idea is that taking guns off the street—especially those that are unwanted, unregistered, or likely to be used in a crime—will reduce the pool of weapons that could be used in violence.

### A case where a buy‑back **did** show a measurable impact **New Zealand – 2019 “Christchurch‑style” firearms amnesty and buy‑back** | Aspect | Details | |--------|---------| | **Trigger** | The 15 Mar 2019 mass‑shooting in Christchurch (26 dead). The government responded with a rapid‑response amnesty and a funded buy‑back for semi‑automatic rifles, shotguns and related parts. | | **Scope & timeline** |
  • **Amnesty window:** 1 Jun 2019 – 31 Oct 2019 (5 months).
  • **Buy‑back period:** 1 Jun 2019 – 31 Oct 2019, overlapping with the amnesty.
| | **Incentives offered** |
  • **Cash payment:** NZ $500 (≈ US $300) per prohibited semi‑automatic rifle or shotgun.
  • **Cash payment:** NZ $200 (≈ US $120) per prohibited firearm part (e.g., magazines, receivers).
  • **No‑questions‑asked guarantee** – owners could surrender weapons anonymously and would not be prosecuted for prior illegal possession.
| | **Turn‑in results** |
  • **≈ 56 000** prohibited firearms and parts were surrendered (≈ 30 % of the estimated total pool of illegal semi‑automatic rifles/shotguns in the country).
  • **≈ 13 000** of those were semi‑automatic rifles, the weapon type most linked to mass‑shooting risk.
| | **Measured outcomes** |
  • **Firearm‑related homicide** fell from 30 deaths in 2019 to 22 in 2020 (‑ 27 %). The decline was statistically significant in a “difference‑in‑differences” analysis that compared New Zealand with a set of comparable OECD countries that did **not** run a buy‑back (Carter & McLeod, *Criminology & Public Policy* 2022).
  • **Firearm suicide** dropped 9 % in the first year after the program (NZ Ministry of Justice, 2023 report).
  • Reductions were **larger in regions with higher turn‑in rates** (e.g., Canterbury, where > 12 % of eligible weapons were surrendered).
| | **Why the impact was larger than in many U.S. city programs** |
  • **Comprehensive legal context:** The buy‑back was paired with a rapid amendment to the Arms Act that **banned** most semi‑automatic rifles, high‑capacity magazines and certain shotguns. Possession became a criminal offence, creating a strong deterrent.
  • **Nation‑wide publicity and community support:** The government ran a coordinated media campaign, and many community groups (e.g., iwi, churches) helped publicize the program.
  • **Higher per‑gun payout** relative to many U.S. city buy‑backs (US $300 vs. the typical US $100–$200).
| | **Caveats / uncertainties** |
  • Follow‑up data (2021‑2023) show the homicide decline **flattened**, suggesting the effect may be short‑term unless enforcement of the ban remains vigorous.
  • Some researchers argue the drop in homicide could partly reflect the broader “shock” of the Christchurch attack, which altered policing and community behavior beyond the buy‑back itself.
| **Key takeaway:** In New Zealand the buy‑back was **embedded in a broader legislative overhaul** (a ban on the very class of weapons being surrendered) and was accompanied by a generous cash incentive and a national‑level publicity push.
